column1: > 00:00|"after midnight"|"""Weren't we going to play mah jong tonight?"" I whisper loudly to Auntie Ying
column2: who's slightly deaf.

column1: Later
column2: she says

column1: Ladies
column2: are you at this meeting or not?"" says Uncle George. After everybody votes unanimously for the Canada gold stock
column3: I go into the kitchen to ask Auntie An-mei why the Joy Luck Club started investing in stocks."|"The Joy Luck Club"|"Amy Tan"

column1: 12:00|noonday|"We returned to the front of the boat
column2: just in time to see the dock moving away from us. Mama and the other ladies were already seated on benches around the pavilion
column3: fanning themselves furiously and slapping the sides of each other's heads when mosquitoes lighted. Baba and Uncle were leaning over a rail
column5: serious voices. My brother and some of his boy cousins had found a long bamboo stick and were poking the water as if they could make the boat go faster. The servants were seated in a cluster at the front
column8: and emptying out hampers of food for a noonday meal of cold dishes."|"The Joy Luck Club"|"Amy Tan"

column1: ap 11:00|eleven|"""Lost eight piece this time. Last time was eleven. What I tell you? Better off lose less!"" I was annoyed
column2: but I couldn't say anything."|"The Joy Luck Club"|"Amy Tan"

column1: ap 04:00|"four o'clock"|"My parents' friends Auntie Su and Uncle Canning picked me up at school one day and took me to the hospital to see my mother. I knew this was serious because everything they said was unnecessary but spoken with solemn importance.
It is now four o'clock
column2: said Uncle Canning

column1: The bus is never on time
column2: said Auntie Su."|"The Joy Luck Club"|"Amy Tan"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"Three days after watching The Ed Sullivan Show
column2: my mother told me what my schedule would be for piano lessons and piano practice. She had talked to Mr. Chong
column3: who lived on the first floor of our apartment building. Mr. Chong was a retired piano teacher and my mother had traded housecleaning services for weekly lessons and a piano for me to practice on every day
column5: from four until six."|"The Joy Luck Club"|"Amy Tan"

column1: 07:00|"7 A.M."|"When I arrived
column2: nobody asked me questions. The authorities looked at my papers and stamped me in. I decided to go first to a San Francisco address given to me by this girl in Peking. The bus put me down on a wide street with cable cars. This was California Street. I walked up this hill and then I saw a tall building. This was Old St. Mary's. Under the church sign
column4: someone had added: ""A Chinese Ceremony to Save Ghosts from Spiritual Unrest 7 A.M. and 8:30 A.M."" I memorized this information in case the authorities asked me where I worshipped my religion. And then I saw another sign across the street. It was painted on the outside of a short building: ""Save Today for Tomorrow
column5: at Bank of America."" And I thought to myself
column6: This is where American people worship. See
column7: even then I was not so dumb! Today that church is the same size
column8: but where that short bank used to be
column9: now there is a tall building
column11: where you and your husband-to-be work and look down on everybody."|"The Joy Luck Club"|"Amy Tan"

column9: now there is a tall building
column11: where you and your husband-to-be work and look down on everybody."|"The Joy Luck Club"|"Amy Tan"

column1: 01:00|"one o'clock in the morning"|"At one o'clock in the morning
column2: I awake to tapping sounds on the window. I must have dozed off and now I feel my body uncramping itself. I'm sitting on the floor
column3: leaning against one of the twin beds. Lili is lying next to me. The others are asleep
column5: sprawled out on the beds and floor. Aiyi is seated at a little table
column6: looking very sleepy. And my father is staring out the window
column7: tapping his fingers on the glass. The last time I listened my father was telling Aiyi about his life since he last saw her. How he had gone to Yenching University
column8: later got a post with a newspaper in Chungking
column10: a young widow. How they later fled together to Shanghai to try to find my mother's family house
column11: but there was nothing there. And then they traveled eventually to Canton and then to Hong Kong
column12: then Haiphong and finally to San Francisco…."|"The Joy Luck Club"|"Amy Tan"

column1: 03:00|"three in the morning"|"At the airport
column2: I am exhausted. I could not sleep last night. Aiyi had followed me into my room at three in the morning
column3: and she instantly fell asleep on one of the twin beds
column4: snoring with the might of a lumberjack. I lay awake thinking about my mother's story
column5: realizing how much I have never known about her
column6: grieving that my sisters and I had both lost her."|"The Joy Luck Club"|"Amy Tan"
